title: Savers lose £13.3m in pensions ‘scam’
text:
Savers lose £13.3m in pensions ‘scam’ Josephine Cumbo, Pensions Correspondent ©Charlie Bibby/FT The London Pensions Fund Authority is trying to cut investment costs 
Hundreds of savers lost over £13m in a suspected sting , the Pensions Regulator has revealed, as it warned savers to be alert to the threat of retirement scams. 
The regulator said the case — affecting 242 pension savers who are believed to have lost £13.3m — involved mass marketing techniques including cold-calling pension scheme members. More Equitable Life compensation deadline looms 
Other “highly suspicious” activity included funds being transferred from pension schemes to trustee personal bank accounts and third-party companies mostly connected to controlling parties. Savers were offered transfer incentives such as cash lump sums. 
However, the regulator said that the pension scheme members were not provided with adequate scheme documentation at the point of transfer and, once entered into a scheme, were unable easily to contact the administrator. 
Following a probe, the regulator suspected that a scam had taken place involving funds of about £13.7m belonging to 242 members which had all but “disappeared” — including through the payment of exorbitant fees and commission payments. Some £400,000 was recovered. 
“This complex case bears many of the hallmarks of a pension scam and should be seen as another reminder of why savers must remain vigilant against the threat of scams, which have a devastating impact on people’s lives,” said Andrew Warwick-Thompson, an executive director at the Pensions Regulator. 
Pension scam losses treble month after Osborne launches reforms 
Pension scam losses more than trebled in the month after George Osborne launched his landmark reforms giving over-55s the freedom to cash in their retirement pots, according to official figures, fuelling fears that more savers could be targeted by criminals. The leap comes after consumer groups and MPs warned that greater safeguards were needed to protect people from losing their life savings to swindlers after the biggest shake-up of the pensions industry in nearly a century came into force in April. 
Read more 
“Our appointment of an independent trustee has helped secure approximately £400,000 from the schemes, however for many hundreds members, hard-earned savings have most likely been lost.” 
“Our message is clear: if you’re cold-called or texted by people claiming they can help you to get early access to the cash in your pension or unusually high investment returns, stop, don’t be tempted, and put the phone down. You’re likely to lose all your money and may face a considerable tax charge.” 
In details of the case published on Monday, three trustees were deemed by the regulator to have “misappropriated scheme funds and exercised poor trustee governance”. 
The regulator disrupted the suspected scam by appointing an independent trustee to oversee 17 pension schemes involved in the case. 
When asked if any individuals were facing criminal action in relation to the case, the regulator said it could not comment on individuals or on the details of its investigations. 
The case comes after the HMRC tightened its registration procedure in 2013 to prevent pension schemes being set up to facilitate scams. It has the power to deregister schemes that break the rules. 
The Pensions Regulator said schemes cannot register without having their registration approved by HMRC. Copyright The Financial Times Limited 2015. You may share using our article tools. Please don't cut articles from FT.com and redistribute by email or post to the web.
